passages.kjv_text: Then Job arose, and rent his mantle, and shaved his head, and fell down upon the ground, and worshipped, And said, Naked came I out of my mother’s womb, and naked shall I return thither: the LORD gave, and the LORD hath taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD. In all this Job sinned not, nor charged God foolishly.
passages.web_text: Then Job arose, and tore his robe, and shaved his head, and fell down on the ground, and worshiped. He said, “Naked I came out of my mother’s womb, and naked shall I return there. Yahweh gave, and Yahweh has taken away. Blessed be Yahweh’s name.” In all this, Job did not sin, nor charge God with wrongdoing.

passages.kjv_text: And not only so, but we glory in tribulations also: knowing that tribulation worketh patience; And patience, experience; and experience, hope: And hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us.
passages.web_text: Not only this, but we also rejoice in our sufferings, knowing that suffering produces perseverance; and perseverance, proven character; and proven character, hope: and hope doesn’t disappoint us, because God’s love has been poured out into our hearts through the Holy Spirit who was given to us.

notes.context: In the face of unimaginable loss, Job's initial response is one of worship and acceptance, not curse. He holds onto God despite his suffering. Paul provides the theological framework for this, explaining how suffering can produce perseverance and character, ultimately leading to a hope that does not disappoint.
notes.reflection: Hope is not the absence of suffering, but the belief in a purpose and a future that exists beyond it. How can we find hope not just in spite of our trials, but through them?
